Line 6: Line 6:
==Social, legal and psychological views on necrophilia==
==Social, legal and psychological views on necrophilia==
===Cause and prevalance===
===Cause and prevalance===
â
Virtually no research has been conducted regarding the prevalance of necrophilic attraction among humans. Klaf and Brown (1958) commented that, "although necrophilia is rarely described, such fantasies are more common than is generally supposed."<ref>Klaf, Franklin S., and Brown, William (1958). "Necrophilia: Brief Review and Case Report," ''the Psychoanalytic Quarterly'', 29(143), 645-652.</ref>
+
Virtually no research has been conducted regarding the prevalance of necrophilic attraction among humans. Klaf and Brown<ref name="klaf">Klaf, Franklin S., and Brown, William (1958). "Necrophilia: Brief Review and Case Report," ''the Psychoanalytic Quarterly'', 29(143), 645-652. "Inhibited forms of necrophilia and necrophilic fantasies may occur more commonly then is generally realized."</ref> (1958) commented that, although rarely described, necrophilic fantasies may occur more often than is generally supposed.
â
Rosman and Resnick (1989) theorized that either of the following situations could be antecedents to necrophilia (pp. 161):<ref>Rosman, Jonathan P., and Resnick, Phillip J. (1989). "Sexual attraction to corpses: a psychiatric review of necrophilia," ''Bulletin of the American Academy of Psychiatry and the Law'', 17, 153-163.</ref>
+
Rosman and Resnick<ref name="rosman">Rosman, Jonathan P., and Resnick, Phillip J. (1989). "Sexual attraction to corpses: a psychiatric review of necrophilia," ''Bulletin of the American Academy of Psychiatry and the Law'', 17, 153-163.</ref> (1989) theorized that either of the following situations could be antecedents to necrophilia (pp. 161):
#The necrophile develops poor self-esteem, perhaps due in part to a significant loss;
#The necrophile develops poor self-esteem, perhaps due in part to a significant loss;
#:(a) He (usually male) is very fearful of rejection by women and he desires a sexual object who is incapable of rejecting him; and/or
#:(a) He (usually male) is very fearful of rejection by women and he desires a sexual object who is incapable of rejecting him; and/or
Line 24: Line 24:
For Erich Fromm, necrophilia is the opposite of [[biophilia]]. The lack of love in the western society leads to necrophilia. Symbols of the necrophile are facades made of concrete and steel, modern weapon systems, the idolatry of the technology of the megamachine ([[technophilia]]), the wasting of resources in [[consumerism]] and the treatment of people as things in [[bureaucracy|bureaucratism]].
For Erich Fromm, necrophilia is the opposite of [[biophilia]]. The lack of love in the western society leads to necrophilia. Symbols of the necrophile are facades made of concrete and steel, modern weapon systems, the idolatry of the technology of the megamachine ([[technophilia]]), the wasting of resources in [[consumerism]] and the treatment of people as things in [[bureaucracy|bureaucratism]].
  +   +
==Necrophilia in history==
  +
To discourage intercourse with a corpse, Ancient Egyptions left deceased beautiful women to decay for "three or four days" before giving them the [[embalmers]].<ref>Brill, Abraham A. (1941). "Necrophilia," ''Journal of Criminal Psychopathology'', 2(4), 433-443.</ref><ref name="klaf" />
